title.en-US: How to quickly perform a syntax check of a JavaScript file

body.en-US:
Recently I came across [a tweet](https://twitter.com/RReverser/status/913779338092466176) by [Ingvar Stepanyan](https://twitter.com/RReverser). He shared the `--check` flag for executing JavaScript files in Node.js. I didn't know about this option.

```
$ node --check some.js

$ node --check some-invalid.js
/Users/stefanjudis/test.js:3
});
^
SyntaxError: Unexpected token }
  at checkScriptSyntax (bootstrap_node.js:457:5)
  at startup (bootstrap_node.js:153:11)
  at bootstrap_node.js:575:3
```

What `--check` enables is a quick check for syntax errors of a JavaScript file without actually executing it. This can be very handy when you're transforming code and just want to make sure the transformation result is valid JavaScript.

On that note: I came accross the [vm module](https://nodejs.org/api/vm.html) which was mentioned in the replies to the tweet. The `vm` module is part of Node core and you can use it to evaluate/execute JavaScript in a sandboxed environment which you control, too.

So far I didn't need this module but you can use it to evaluate and syntax check JavaScript files from within your scripts.

```javascript
const vm = require('vm');
const script = new vm.Script('var a =');
```

The constructor of `vm.Script` throws an exceptions if there are any syntax errors. 

This module looks quite interesting. So, if you're dealing with generated code you might want to check it out. ;)

title.en-US: The for accessibility required `caption` element in HTML  tables

body.en-US:
I'm sitting at the airport in Bangkok right now (yeah vacation!!!) and am reading [an article](http://adrianroselli.com/2017/11/hey-its-still-ok-to-use-tables.html) by [Adrian Roselli](https://twitter.com/aardrian) on tables regarding accessibility. It can not be that hard to build an accessible table. It's just the `table` element including other `th`, `tr` and `td` elements, right? Not quite... The article goes into beautiful detail on what it means to build an accessible table, and in the first few paragraphs of it, it already included something that was new to me ‚Äì the `caption` element in tables. ```html
Populations of cities
City Population
``` `caption` is one element you don't see "in the wild" very often. [The spec ](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/tables.html#the-caption-element) defines it as follows: > [...] the first element child of a table element. > The caption element represents the title of the table that is its parent, if it has a parent and that is a table element. Defining a title and some additional information for a table makes total sense to me, and more surprising than its rare usage is only that the `caption` element even has its own mention in the [techniques for WCAG 2.0](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20-TECHS/H39.html). üò≤ That said, my next `table` definitely includes a `caption` element.

Ready to deploy this project and start collecting your #TIL ("Today I learned") posts? The setup of a statically deployed site on [Netlify](https://www.netlify.com) with data handled in [Contentful](https://www.contentful.com) takes only a few minutes! 

__Let's do it and deploy it!__

[![Deploy to Netlify](https://www.netlify.com/img/deploy/button.svg)](https://app.netlify.com/start/deploy?repository=https://github.com/stefanjudis/netlify-contentful-react-static-site-example)

After you hit this (‚òùÔ∏è) button the following steps has to be done (it's only configuration ‚Äì promise!):

## Configuration of the one-click deploy on Netlify

![Netlify installation screen](//images.ctfassets.net/3rj6js5xm0db/5xCWJ0pi0gm4YKWwA2WWEu/b240c8a188d10df633a81815967acf3a/netlify1.jpg)

Netlify will ask you to connect with GitHub. This is needed because Netlify will create __a new public repository in your GitHub account__ and add the code of [this repository](https://github.com/stefanjudis/netlify-contentful-react-client-side-example) to it. You then have a complete copy of the source code and can start changing it to your needs.

### Needed configuration parameters

After you granted permission to GitHub it will ask you for the following values:

__Repository name__: the name of the repository that will be created in your GitHub account (this one is completely up to you)

__Contentful Space ID__: the ID of the Contentful space storing all your learnings

__Contentful Content Management Token__: a Contentful WRITE token which is used to set up Contentful with the right data structures

__Contentful Content Delivery Token__: a Contentful READ-only token which will power the React application

The Contentful-related values will be available later in `process.env` and will be used by the React application powering your learnings. So, let's have a look at where you can find these values!

### Setup up Contentful

First you have to log in to Contentful and create a new space in Contentful.

![Creat space dialog in Contentful](//images.ctfassets.net/3rj6js5xm0db/6u5R40vdNmmQCK00AqqUoo/481d55925456ec621c4df7decbb6dded/netlify2.jpg)

#### Create Content Delivery API Key and Space ID

You have to go to "Settings" and "API keys". This section is devived into "Content delivery / preview tokens" and "Content management tokens". The former are tokens that are READ-only and can be used in your application to fetch your content and the latter are READ/WRITE tokens which sould be kept private in any case.

In the "Content delivery / preview tokens" you can then create new READ API keys which will include a Content Delivery Key and also show you your space ID.

![Dialog to create Content Delivery and Preview API keys](//images.ctfassets.net/3rj6js5xm0db/69ZKXSkpywM6I0w280oO6I/03b4180800afa8a77740b6c9625f9906/netlify3.jpg)

#### Create Personal Access Token

Personal Access Tokens are Content Management Tokens that have the same rights you as the user who creates them has (yes... they're dangerous). You can use them to write automation scripts or, like in this case, bootstrap new created spaces. 

![Dialog to create a Personal Access Token](//images.ctfassets.net/3rj6js5xm0db/5sbDhZYXf2aAwQaGWqYYog/51aed66b9b61148eb228e0c307538593/netlify4.jpg)

## Deploy

__Enjoy and hit "Save & deploy"!__

![Deployment dialog in Netlify](//images.ctfassets.net/3rj6js5xm0db/64SX3h58qsssYOMIaqcYCS/74f5891bd58a2467db7b7ea992067747/netlify5.jpg)

Netlify will start deploying your site and setting up your Contentful space in the deployment process.

### Let Contentful trigger rebuilds in Netlify

During the first deployment an installation script created a webhook URL in Netlify which will trigger rebuilds of your static site. You can use this URL to let Contentful trigger rebuilds on Netlify.

![Webhooks defined in Netlify](//images.ctfassets.net/3rj6js5xm0db/3HOeAbQ8Kc6GI48wQUSCuI/b3fc61d856e53e3fd990098b04e28875/netlify11.jpg)

Grab the URL to under "Settings" and "Build & Deploy" and get ready for the last step. The connection webhook connection from Contentful to Netlify.

![Add netlify WebHook Dialog in Contentful](//images.ctfassets.net/3rj6js5xm0db/4YwJ2XahAQoo0iAQC2Iwcm/41d1062428e012a2b605ae4c0ee4b3eb/netlify12.jpg)

In Contentful you can go to "Settings" and "Webhooks". A Netlify Webhook template is already waiting for you to accept the URL.

## Clean up

Let's go to the deployed preview URL.

![Deployed result telling that the Personal Access Token should be removed](//images.ctfassets.net/3rj6js5xm0db/6RiFujp7tCykYc4kMeCg4O/459be8dcde800c2b3808ddb7223d0f4e/netlify6.jpg)

Whooops... there are still some things to do. Remember that the Personal Access Token has WRITE rights? Your Contentful space is now set up which means that you can revoke the token (it's the same place where you created it) and remove the environment variable `REACT_APP_CTF_CMA_TOKEN` from the Netlify environment variables.

![Environment variables defined in Netlify](//images.ctfassets.net/3rj6js5xm0db/2cXRHJyW8c8EMqkaIYAacC/c29ae041450c124d573a14525ce67a9d/netlify10.jpg)

__Always treat your WRITE tokens carefully!__ 

### And you're done!

![Finaly Today I learned Micro blogging done](//images.ctfassets.net/3rj6js5xm0db/6v9u2sei1aUcaEGi88wUUw/ced9e577bf42e9af00ba73d5471f3794/netlify8.jpg)

Congratulations! You can now start documenting your daily learnings easily!

*To start working on it locally check out [the Readme of the project](https://github.com/stefanjudis/netlify-contentful-react-static-site-example).*
